name: Titanium dioxide
what_it_is: A bright white pigment (synthetic, man-made).
common_in: chewing gum, icing, sprinkles, tablet coatings
child_note: EU banned in 2022 over genotoxicity concerns; GB/US still allow with limits.
who_should_take_care: Anyone avoiding additives flagged by regulators
headline_risk_or_benefit: EU ban; differing views among authorities.
region_status_short: EU/NI: banned • GB: permitted • US: permitted (≤1% in food)
quick_advice: Choose products without E171.
sources_primary: [{"title": "EFSA 2021: E171 no longer considered safe", "url": "https://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/news/titanium-dioxide-e171-no-longer-considered-safe-when-used-food-additive"}, {"title": "eCFR 21 CFR 73.575 (US rule)", "url": "https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-21/chapter-I/subchapter-A/part-73/subpart-A/section-73.575"}, {"title": "EU framework: Regulation (EC) No 1333/2008 (food additives)", "url": "https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2008/1333/oj"}, {"title": "EU additive specifications: Regulation (EU) No 231/2012", "url": "https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2012/231/oj"}, {"title": "JECFA additives database (WHO/FAO)", "url": "https://apps.who.int/food-additives-contaminants-jecfa-database/chemSearch.aspx"}, {"title": "US eCFR Title 21 (FDA) \u2014 Food Additives", "url": "https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-21"}]
uk_grade_note: Colour: brighter synthetics carry higher weight; naturals lower.

name: Potassium bromate
what_it_is: An oxidiser formerly used to strengthen dough.
child_note: BANNED in UK/EU. California bans sales from 2027.
who_should_take_care: Everyone—avoid
headline_risk_or_benefit: Rodent carcinogen signals; many bans.
region_status_short: EU/GB: banned • US: discouraged; CA ban from 2027
quick_advice: Skip any product listing bromate.
sources_primary: [{"title": "UK ban SI 1990/399", "url": "https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/1990/399/made"}, {"title": "California AB-418 (2027)", "url": "https://www.gov.ca.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/AB-418-Signing.pdf"}, {"title": "EU framework: Regulation (EC) No 1333/2008 (food additives)", "url": "https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2008/1333/oj"}, {"title": "EU additive specifications: Regulation (EU) No 231/2012", "url": "https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2012/231/oj"}, {"title": "JECFA additives database (WHO/FAO)", "url": "https://apps.who.int/food-additives-contaminants-jecfa-database/chemSearch.aspx"}, {"title": "US eCFR Title 21 (FDA) \u2014 Food Additives", "url": "https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-21"}]
uk_grade_note: Red-flag additive in UK context; presence can drop grade to F.

name: Tartrazine (FD&C Yellow 5)
what_it_is: Synthetic azo dye (man-made).
child_note: EU requires label about possible effects on activity/attention in children (for certain azo dyes).
who_should_take_care: Families tracking behavioural triggers
headline_risk_or_benefit: Warning label in EU; permitted with limits.
region_status_short: EU/GB: permitted (warning) • US: permitted (must declare name)
quick_advice: Prefer naturally coloured options for kids.
sources_primary: [{"title": "EFSA Southampton study context", "url": "https://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/news/efsa-evaluates-southampton-study-food-additives-and-child-behaviour"}, {"title": "EU framework: Regulation (EC) No 1333/2008 (food additives)", "url": "https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2008/1333/oj"}, {"title": "EU additive specifications: Regulation (EU) No 231/2012", "url": "https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2012/231/oj"}, {"title": "JECFA additives database (WHO/FAO)", "url": "https://apps.who.int/food-additives-contaminants-jecfa-database/chemSearch.aspx"}, {"title": "US eCFR Title 21 (FDA) \u2014 Food Additives", "url": "https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-21"}]
uk_grade_note: Colour: brighter synthetics carry higher weight; naturals lower.

name: Sodium benzoate
what_it_is: Salt of benzoic acid (synthetic, man-made).
child_note: Featured in ‘Southampton’ mixtures with certain dyes; evidence mixed.
who_should_take_care: Families tracking behavioural triggers
headline_risk_or_benefit: Permitted with limits.
quick_advice: Prefer benzoate-free drinks for kids where possible.
sources_primary: [{"title": "Lancet 2007 Southampton study", "url": "https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(07)61306-3/fulltext"}, {"title": "EU framework: Regulation (EC) No 1333/2008 (food additives)", "url": "https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2008/1333/oj"}, {"title": "EU additive specifications: Regulation (EU) No 231/2012", "url": "https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2012/231/oj"}, {"title": "JECFA additives database (WHO/FAO)", "url": "https://apps.who.int/food-additives-contaminants-jecfa-database/chemSearch.aspx"}, {"title": "US eCFR Title 21 (FDA) \u2014 Food Additives", "url": "https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-21"}]

name: Curcumin
what_it_is: Curcumin is a colouring ingredient used to make foods look appealing (some are natural extracts, others are synthetic).
child_note: Bright synthetic colours can encourage overconsumption; some azo dyes carry an EU behaviour warning.
headline_risk_or_benefit: Widely used; limits apply depending on food.
quick_advice: For kids, prefer naturally coloured options and keep bright colours as occasional treats.

name: Sorbic acid
what_it_is: Sorbic acid helps stop spoilage and keeps foods safe for longer.
common_in: bread, cheese, soft drinks, pickles, cured meats
child_note: Sulfites can trigger symptoms in a subset of asthmatics; nitrites are tightly controlled in cured meats.
who_should_take_care: People with asthma (sulfites); Infants (avoid cured meats)
headline_risk_or_benefit: Widely used; limits apply depending on food.
quick_advice: Rotate choices; for kids, lean on fresher options and simple labels. Asthmatics should check for sulfites.
sources_primary: [{"title": "EFSA: nitrites/nitrates explainer", "url": "https://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/corporate/pub/nitritesandnitrates170614"}, {"title": "EU framework: Regulation (EC) No 1333/2008 (food additives)", "url": "https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2008/1333/oj"}, {"title": "EU additive specifications: Regulation (EU) No 231/2012", "url": "https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2012/231/oj"}, {"title": "JECFA additives database (WHO/FAO)", "url": "https://apps.who.int/food-additives-contaminants-jecfa-database/chemSearch.aspx"}, {"title": "US eCFR Title 21 (FDA) \u2014 Food Additives", "url": "https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-21"}]

name: Propionic acid
what_it_is: Propionic acid helps stop spoilage and keeps foods safe for longer.
common_in: bread, cheese, soft drinks, pickles, cured meats
child_note: Sulfites can trigger symptoms in a subset of asthmatics; nitrites are tightly controlled in cured meats.
who_should_take_care: People with asthma (sulfites); Infants (avoid cured meats)
headline_risk_or_benefit: Widely used; limits apply depending on food.
quick_advice: Rotate choices; for kids, lean on fresher options and simple labels. Asthmatics should check for sulfites.

name: Malic acid
what_it_is: Malic acid adjusts acidity (pH) for taste, texture, or safety.
child_note: Acidic drinks can affect tooth enamel; use straws and keep to mealtimes.
who_should_take_care: People with reflux; Those advised to limit phosphates
headline_risk_or_benefit: Widely used; limits apply depending on food.
quick_advice: Mostly fine; if you have reflux or kidney conditions, check with your clinician about high-acid foods.

child_note: Acidic drinks can affect tooth enamel; use straws and keep to mealtimes.
who_should_take_care: People with reflux; Those advised to limit phosphates
headline_risk_or_benefit: Widely used; limits apply depending on food.
quick_advice: Mostly fine; if you have reflux or kidney conditions, check with your clinician about high-acid foods.

name: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C)
what_it_is: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) helps stop fats and oils from going rancid.
child_note: Snacks with added antioxidants are often ultra-processed; keep them occasional.
headline_risk_or_benefit: Widely used; limits apply depending on food.
quick_advice: If you prefer fewer synthetic antioxidants, pick products using tocopherols or no added antioxidants.

name: Alginic acid
what_it_is: Alginic acid is a plant/seaweed/fermentation gum or fibre that adds thickness or helps keep mixtures stable.
child_note: High-gum products can be filling yet low in nutrients.
headline_risk_or_benefit: Widely used; limits apply depending on food.
quick_advice: If you have a sensitive gut, test tolerance and choose products with simpler gum blends.

name: Lecithins (soy/sunflower/egg)
what_it_is: Lecithins (soy/sunflower/egg) helps oil and water mix and keeps textures smooth.
child_note: Ultra-smooth textures can encourage overeating in kids; keep treats occasional.
headline_risk_or_benefit: Widely used; limits apply depending on food.
quick_advice: If you find emulsifier-heavy foods bother your digestion, choose simpler recipes or fewer emulsifiers.

what_it_is: Sodium ferrocyanide keeps powders free-flowing and prevents clumps.

quick_advice: If you prefer, choose coarse salts/spices without anti-caking agents.

name: Sorbitol
what_it_is: Sorbitol provides sweetness with less or no sugar.
why_it_is_used: Sweet taste with fewer calories or dental impact.
common_in: diet drinks, sugar-free sweets, chewing gum
child_note: High-intensity sweeteners keep the sweet taste habit—use sparingly.
headline_risk_or_benefit: Widely used; limits apply depending on food.
quick_advice: For kids, make water/milk the default. Sugar alcohols can cause tummy upset in excess.

what_it_is: Aspartame provides sweetness with less or no sugar.
why_it_is_used: Sweet taste with fewer calories or dental impact.
common_in: diet drinks, sugar-free sweets, chewing gum
child_note: High-intensity sweeteners keep the sweet taste habit—use sparingly.
headline_risk_or_benefit: Widely used; limits apply depending on food.
quick_advice: For kids, make water/milk the default. Sugar alcohols can cause tummy upset in excess.

name: Dimethylpolysiloxane (antifoam)
what_it_is: Dimethylpolysiloxane (antifoam) gives fruits/sweets a shine or prevents sticking.
child_note: Glazes are surface-only and present in tiny amounts.
headline_risk_or_benefit: Widely used; limits apply depending on food.
quick_advice: If you want plant-only coatings, avoid shellac and beeswax.

quick_advice: Choose BVO‑free drinks.
